[[PSYC 304]]

9-12-23

#### [[PSYC304 L2 History of Psychology and Neurointroduction#Types of Brain]] cont.	
> Fish: primary hind + midbrain usage, essentially no forebrain
> Rat: significant olfactory bulb but only a little more cortex use than fish
> Dog: notable forebrain, intelligent animals (understand pointing!)
> Chimpanzee: smarter than dog, more forebrain, etc. 

#### Exceptions to the "rules"
> Parrots: relatively simple brain, but can understand categories, subcategories, counting and "zero," 
   Dolphins: complex brain, but not nearly as much demonstrable intelligence as, say, a dog

##### Bigger brain is not better
While most animals fall on the same line of brain-body ratio, size is less important than a **higher brain:body ratio** (disproportionately bigger brains)
`#` of brain cells per unit of mass: 
	**Denser brain correlates with higher intelligence**
	Sophistication of cellular connections correlates with higher intelligence (but hard to measure)

#### Brain Matter 
**Gray matter** 
> Cell bodies of neurons 
> Small unmyelinated neurons 

**White matter**
> Connections between neurons:
> Myelinated axons

Before imaging: **staining** to see gray vs white matter
[![](data:image/png;base64,)
](app://obsidian.md/index.html#page=20)
Nissl, cresyl violet: gray matter
	Stains cell bodies (reveals gray matter)
	Golgi stain: shows individual neurons
	Nissl: better for observing brain regions
Fiber stain: white matter
	Stains fiber, aka insulating glia cells aka white matter

### Basic cell types 
**Neurons**
	"Communicating cells" (altho there are many other cells which communicate, e.g. endocrine)
	Axon produce action potential–virtually only cell to do so 
		Extremely fast and precisely targeted
**Glia**
	"Glue": connective tissue

Signal travels dendrite -> soma (cell body) -> axon -> terminals

### Shapes of neuron 
Pyramidal neuron: triangle shape, tons of dendrites
	In cortex
![[Screen Shot 2023-09-14 at 9.58.02 AM.png]]
Stellate
	Cerebellar
![[Screen Shot 2023-09-14 at 9.58.54 AM.png]]
Purkinje
	Cerebellar (in cortex)
	Signal integration
![[Screen Shot 2023-09-14 at 9.59.56 AM.png]]

### 2 types of neuron 
**Projection:** 
> **long axon** which projects to different brain region
> 	wire, signal 
> 	axon can be as long as you want: can regenerate action potential indefinitely 

**Interneurons:** 
> **short axon**, only projects locally (same brain region)
> 	(pyramidal) **congregated around gaps between projection neurons**: potentiate, modify signal between projection neurons
> 	**"make sense" of sensory information** 
> 	usually **inhibitory** in nature: synchronize activity across many neurons


### Glial cells 
**Macroglia**
> 3 types: astrocyte, schwann cell, oligodendocytes
> **Schwann cells** 
> 	Not found in brain or spinal cord (peripheral nervous system)
> 	Myelinate axons–wrap selves around, only **myelinate a single axon**
> **Oligodendrocytes**
> 	Oligo = "several"
> 	In brain + spinal cord (central nervous system)
> 	Will wrap themselves around **myelinate several axons** 
> **Astrocytes**
> 	"Star"
> 	Major support cells 
> 	Influence neuron function
> 	Glial scarring = made of astrocytes
> 	Most abundant CNS neuroglia 
> 	Star shaped "feet" **wrap around blood vessels: part of the blood-brain barrier**
> 	**Mediate all oxygen, glucose, nutrition in brain** 
> 	**Wrapped around synapses**
> **Glial networks**
> 	Made of astrocytes
> 	The part of Golgi's reticular theory that was actually correct
> 	Ensures homogeneity across synapses (e.g. transmission of potassium, calcium)
> 	Gap junctions: interneurons in PFC 

**Microglia**
> Immune system role in brain
> Blood-brain barrier: pathogens that are relatively easy to handle in other regions can be fatal in brain
> 	Microglia are the line of defense in case anything trespasses
> Covered in receptors: if they detect presence of bacteria, they **activate (primed state)**
> 	Begin searching for foreign body, when they find it, they inflate **(active state)** and digest the foreign body 
> Dysfunction may be related to autoimmune disorders


### Tripartite synapse 
Pre-synaptic axon terminal 
Post-synaptic dendrite receptors
Astrocyte wraps around synapse itself, protecting it and transmitting chemical messages: **gliotransmitters** 
	Influence strength of synapse + message
	Can digest and remove unhelpful messages: enhance learning and memory
Brain cancer = glial cell growth 


## Molecular biology
##### "Central dogma of molecular biology"
**Transcription: DNA -> RNA**
**Translation: RNA -> protein** 

#### Protein function 
Transport, structural + mechanical, enzymes, cell signaling, energy, acid-base science, fluid balance, antibodies, hormones
Basis for neuronal function

**From DNA** 
	Transcription into RNA, splicing (removal of introns and composition of exons) into mRNA
	Activators and repressors determine if transcription occurs: gene will only be expressed if all necessary activators are present *and* the repressor is absent 

### **Epigenetics**
Non-genetic transmission of generational information 
	**Histone** modification (DNA wraps around histones)
	Life experience can change how tightly or loosely the DNA wraps around histones
		Looser wrap: more opportunity for transcription to occur because the transcribers can reach the genes / tighter wrap makes it less accessible to transcribers
	Epigenetic changes to the chromatin (what chromosomes consist of) may result from development, environmental chemicals, drugs, aging, diet
	Epigenetic changes may result in cancer, autoimmune disease, mental disorders, diabetes, etc. 

### Soma: ER and Golgi apparatus
If ribosome is free: will create proteins in intracellular fluid
Rough ER: synthesized proteins will be packaged in golgi
